name: Adam B. Schiff
content:
It’s been a painful two weeks for Californians. Last week, a gunman opened fire at a San Jose light rail yard, killing 9 people in the 5th deadliest mass shooting in our state’s history. And just two days ago, a shooting at an LA County fire station claimed the life of a firefighter and turned yet another public space into a site of tragedy.

It’s not just mass shootings. Californians are dying of gun violence every day in tragedies that don’t make the headlines but devastate families and communities — in just the past 72 hours, 15 Californians were killed by gun violence.

It seems like every time we turn on the news or look at our phones, there’s breaking news of another shooting. We cannot allow ourselves to become numb to this violence. We cannot let this become the new normal, even though it often seems like it is.

We owe it to victims, to the loved ones they left behind, and survivors of gun violence to champion the reforms that could have spared their lives or protected them from harm. All Americans, Democrats and Republicans want an end to this, but GOP leaders in Congress refuse to budge. If they can summon even an ounce of political courage, we can tackle gun violence head on, and make a real difference.

We can expand federal background checks and red flag laws. We can close dangerous gun show and private sales loopholes and ban high-capacity clips and assault weapons. And we can pass my Equal Access to Justice for Victims of Gun Violence Act, which would ensure that the gun industry – including manufacturers, sellers and interest groups – can be held accountable when it acts with negligence and disregard for public safety. We are not powerless to end gun violence. We just need the will and courage to act.

It’s time for Republican lawmakers to decide whether money from the gun lobby is worth more than the precious lives lost to the daily tide of gun violence. I know where I stand.

https://abc7.com/shooting-at-agua-dulce-fire-station-leaves-1-firefighter-dead-1-wounded/10728889/

ABC7.COM
County firefighter fatally shoots fellow firefighter, wounds captain and takes own life, sources say

Eliminating the stepped up basis would supercharge the death tax.

It would hit family farms and small businesses with huge tax bills when it comes time to pass their operation along to the next generation.

Most devastated will be families who experience an unexpected death, who don’t have time to plan around it.

Children whose fathers die in a tractor accident, whose mothers are killed in a car wreck, those are going to be the people paying this new tax.

Children whose parents are gone too soon.

It’s wrong. Death shouldn’t be a taxable event.

name: Bill Johnson
content: Did your lights come on when you switched them on this morning? Did your toaster or microwave work? Then the electricity in your home must have been on…and, the electricity you used may have been generated by the Cardinal Plant in Brilliant, Ohio along the Ohio River. The Cardinal Plant occupies a unique place in the history of electric power generation. It represents the first-ever alliance of an investor-owned electric utility — American Electric Power (AEP) — and a member-owned electric utility — Buckeye Power, the power generation arm of Ohio’s Electric Cooperatives, Inc. — to operate a power plant serving different sectors of consumers. Buckeye Power is comprised of 25 rural electric cooperatives, and serves nearly 40% of the state’s land area…380,000 homes, businesses, and farms. Some people don’t want to hear this, but it’s vital that we have affordable and reliable baseload electricity…and coal-fired power generation is a vital source of baseload electricity for our national energy grid.

name: Chellie Pingree
content:
This AM, I am visiting a Piping Plover colony at Popham Beach with Maine Audubon. These tiny birds play an essential role in Maine’s ecosystem by controlling the insect + small crustacean populations on beaches. Sadly, they had long been endangered due the loss of their habitats.

Through careful conservation these birds are rebounding which is good news for our environment and health. We need a coordinated government response to fully support wildlife + endangered species habitats, like those of the Piping Plover, that’s why I’ve cosponsored H. Res 69.

name: Gregory F. Murphy
content:
Since 1976, the Hyde Amendment has been included in every government funding bill with wide bipartisan support. The amendment ensures no taxpayer funds are appropriated through the Labor, Health and Human Services appropriations bill to support abortion or insurance plans that include elective abortions. For nearly 45 years, this bipartisan provision has saved millions of lives.

Joe Biden was an ardent supporter of the Hyde Amendment for decades. This is yet another egregious example of his flip-flopping and catering to the radical left.

As your member of Congress, I have pledged to vote against any government appropriations bill that weakens or eliminates the Hyde Amendment. This amendment must be included because every life is a miracle.
text: since hyde amendment included every government funding bill wide bipartisan support amendment ensures taxpayer funds appropriated labor health human services appropriations bill support abortion insurance plans include elective abortions nearly years bipartisan provision saved millions livesjoe biden ardent supporter hyde amendment decades yet another egregious example flipflopping catering radical leftas member congress pledged vote government appropriations bill weakens eliminates hyde amendment amendment must included every life miracle

name: Richard J. Durbin
content:
Enjoyed visiting mHUB Chicago today to discuss how a shortage of semiconductor chips is impacting the American automotive industry, including assembly plants in Chicago and Belvidere. In 1990, the U.S. represented 37% of global manufacturing capacity. Today, only 12% of semiconductors are manufactured in the United States. That needs to change.

Next week, the Senate will continue work on critically important legislation that would make major investments in the domestic production of these chips. It’s just one of many reasons why I support the U.S. Innovation and Competition Act and why I hope we can pass this legislation with strong bipartisan support.

name: Terri Sewell
content:
In 1965, the Foot Soldiers of the Civil Rights movement marched 54 miles from Selma to Montgomery to demand voting rights. Along the way, they stayed overnight at camp sites owned by 3 African American farmers who Dr. King called “ordinary people with extraordinary vision.”

Today, these sites are on the National Trust for Historic Preservation's list of our country's most endangered historic places. We must do everything in our power to ensure these sites are preserved so that future generations can learn from the sacrifices of those whose shoulders we stand on.

APNEWS.COM
Selma-to-Montgomery march camps top list of endangered sites
text: foot soldiers civil rights movement marched miles selma montgomery demand voting rights along way stayed overnight camp sites owned african american farmers dr king called ordinary people extraordinary visiontoday sites national trust historic preservations list countrys endangered historic places must everything power ensure sites preserved future generations learn sacrifices whose shoulders stand onapnewscomselmatomontgomery march camps top list endangered sites

name: Brendan F. Boyle
content:
Today, I called upon United States Attorney General Merrick Garland to conduct a full and thorough investigation into retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn’s recent calls for violence against the United States, and his pattern of behavior that poses a threat to our national security.

Such blatant and dangerous calls for continued violence against the United States and our government are reprehensible. These sentiments expressed by retired Lt. Gen. Flynn, when coupled with his previous behavior and connections to extremist groups that initiated the attack on the U.S. Capitol, warrant a thorough DOJ-led investigation.

A copy of my full letter is attached to this post and it can also be found here: https://boyle.house.gov/sites/boyle.house.gov/files/Boyle%20Letter%20to%20DOJ%20on%20Michael%20Flynn_6.3.2021.pdf

name: Michael F. Bennet
content:
The Pikes Peak Outdoor Recreation Alliance has done excellent work for Colorado's outdoor recreation industry. The members I met with today, including co-founders Becky Leinweber and David Leinweber, understand that healthy forests are critical to maintaining the industry.

Becky said, "Conservation and recreation go hand in hand.." and I couldn't have said it better myself.

We need to invest in restoring our forests and watersheds to protect our lands and prevent wildfires like the Bear Creek Fire, which devastated this area.

I'll keep working to pass our Outdoor Restoration Partnership Act to create good-paying jobs in forest and watershed restoration projects across the country, lowering the risk of catastrophic wildfire to protect Colorado’s watersheds and boost the state’s economy.

name: Lisa Murkowski
content: While in Talkeetna, I met with Israel Mahay, owner of Mahay's Jet Boat Adventures. Israel’s dad, Steve Mahay, founded the business in 1975 and they have been an important team-player in their community ever since. I appreciate Israel for talking me through some of the challenges they experienced throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as new challenges that are arising as we get closer and closer to normal. Israel did a great job of explaining the unique and dynamic partnerships between local businesses in a small community like Talkeetna. Together, the businesses all make up a delicate ecosystem in their efforts to provide the ultimate customer experience to everyone who visits— if one business is hurting, the entire community feels the impact in some way.

name: Matt Cartwright
content:
Northeastern Pennsylvania is home to the hardest workers I know, and I was proud to introduce some of them to U.S. Labor Secretary Marty Walsh yesterday. We visited GMS Piling Products, a steel fabrication company in Hanover Township that makes products we’ll use to modernize our infrastructure. The American Jobs Plan would invest $115 billion in repairing roads and bridges. That means more demand for companies like GMS, but they’ve been struggling to find skilled workers for a while.

That’s why the American Jobs Plan would also provide $50 billion for workforce development programs like apprenticeships and partnerships with high schools and technical schools – to equip people with the skills for good-paying manufacturing jobs like the openings at GMS.

These investments will make Northeastern Pennsylvania stronger, and I look forward to working with Secretary Walsh and the Biden Administration to advance this transformational American Jobs Plan.

My sincere thanks to Gene and Allison Swindell for showing us around and introducing us to your great employees.

content: Had a great visit at Lonza in Greenwood yesterday, and loved meeting with some of the military vets working at the facility. Lonza may be a Swiss company, but they don't shy away from honoring our veterans and proudly displaying the American flag. Years ago, I presented them with a flag that was flown over our nation's Capitol. Lonza then took that flag and hired a veteran to design a way to incorporate it into their lobby as a tribute to all who have served. Thank you Lonza Group for your investment in our community, and your commitment to hiring our heroes!

name: Doris O. Matsui
content:
In the #AmericanRescuePlan, we invested more than $15 billion to speed up the distribution and administration of COVID-19 vaccines across the country. This has allowed us to get more shots in people’s arms and end this pandemic, and has ensured that we have the people on the ground and resources necessary to vaccinate as many people as possible, such as here at John F. Kennedy High School in Sacramento.

But we must continue to break down barriers to vaccination – looking at how we can help with transportation and reminding folks that you can get a vaccine without an appointment now, and for no cost. We must act boldly to improve distribution of the vaccine across the country and focus on reaching our most vulnerable communities, such as through community vaccination centers and mobile vaccination units.

name: Doris O. Matsui
content:
It was an honor to join Mayor Darrell Steinberg, Councilmember Katie Valenzuela, SAFE Credit Union, Visit Sacramento, and Fran Halbakken at the ribbon cutting of the newly expanded and renovated SAFE Credit Union Convention Center in the heart of Sacramento’s Entertainment District.

This convention center complex is a cutting edge, culturally vibrant corridor where residents and visitors can walk, admire public art, and get a taste of what our city has to offer.

Sacramento is ever growing as a thriving cultural hub, but we always pay reverence to our city’s illustrious past. We build community-conscious spaces that seek to improve the lives of the people. We innovate while honoring our history.

I was thrilled to celebrate the convention center today, and I’m excited for Sacramentans and visitors to come visit this amazing space.

name: Lisa Murkowski
content:
I am excited to announce that Launch Alaska, a startup accelerator based in Anchorage that works with entrepreneurs developing innovative solutions to tackle climate change, transportation, energy, water, and food challenges, was one of ten organizations nationally to receive a competitive $1 million award from the U.S. Department of Energy DOE) Energy Program for Innovation Clusters (EPIC) initiative. I was proud to fund this program through my role on the Appropriations Committee. The EPIC initiative is overseen by DOE’s Office of Technology Transition, and seeks to encourage ecosystems for testing, validation, and demonstration of technologies to help them scale and enhance U.S. energy manufacturing competitiveness. I can’t wait to see how Launch Alaska is able to put this award to use, and what exciting innovation it will lead to. https://www.murkowski.senate.gov/press/release/launch-alaska-awarded-1-million-doe-grant-to-strengthen-energy-innovation-ecosystems-

MURKOWSKI.SENATE.GOV
Launch Alaska Awarded $1 Million DOE Grant to Strengthen Energy Innovation Ecosystems | U.S. Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska

name: Jerry Moran
content:
Expanding rural America’s access to high-speed broadband is critical to making certain all Kansans have the capability to compete in today’s digital economy and workplace. COVID-19 has created an increased reliance on high-speed internet, and expanding rural broadband will contribute to preserve Kansas’ way of life while also working to close the digital divide.

Recently, I cosponsored the Rural Connectivity Advancement Program Act, which supports increased deployment of reliable broadband in Kansas and across the country by providing additional resources to the FCC to target underserved areas and boost connectivity. During my time in Congress, I have worked diligently to improve broadband access to rural Kansans and will continue to work to ensure all Kansans have access to reliable and high quality broadband.

name: John Hoeven
content:
After the barley malting facility closed, we made the case to ADM to open this plant in North Dakota, and now we’re working to realize four ways in which this single project will benefit our state.

Beyond the direct benefits to our agriculture sector, this crushing plant presents opportunities to continue growing North Dakota’s role as a global energy powerhouse. This includes supporting the production of renewable diesel, providing an additional revenue stream to the Spiritwood station and more opportunities to demonstrate that our state is the leader in developing CCUS technologies, which will enable us to produce more energy with better environmental stewardship.

name: Alan S. Lowenthal
content:
I am proud to represent the largest Cambodian community in the U.S., and many Cambodian Americans still have familial and business connections to Cambodia. Since I came to Congress, I have been speaking out against the human rights abuses perpetuated against the Cambodian people by Prime Minister Hun Sen regime, and calling for free and fair elections in Cambodia. When I heard that U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman would be visiting Cambodia, I urged her to meet with Kem Sokha, leader of the political opposition party CNRP. I am glad to see that the Deputy Secretary did in fact meet and engage with independent voices in Cambodia. Our nation must lead the fight for human rights around the world.

https://twitter.com/DeputySecState/status/1399721644487233541

TWITTER.COM
Wendy R. Sherman on Twitter

name: Theodore E. Deutch
content:
June marks Pride Month, a time to celebrate the LGBTQ community while also remembering that the fight for equality is not over.

2021 marks 52 years since the monumental 1969 Stonewall riots, a turning point in the fight for LGBTQ equality. However, this community continues to be subjected to hate crimes, gun violence, and widespread discrimination. Our society must not tolerate this bigotry. I am proud to stand with South Florida’s LGBTQ community to fight for their fair treatment and equality under the law.

On February 25th, the House passed the Equality Act which protects LGBTQ people from discrimination in public accommodations and facilities, education, federal funding, employment, housing, credit, and the jury system. I urge the Senate to pass this important piece of legislation which would be a triumph for civil rights and equality.

This Pride month, we must not stay silent as states consider and pass transphobic and homophobic policies that threaten the LGBTQ community. We will stand up against hate to ensure that love wins.
text: june marks pride month time celebrate lgbtq community also remembering fight equality over2021 marks years since monumental stonewall riots turning point fight lgbtq equality however community continues subjected hate crimes gun violence widespread discrimination society must tolerate bigotry proud stand south floridas lgbtq community fight fair treatment equality lawon february 25th house passed equality act protects lgbtq people discrimination public accommodations facilities education federal funding employment housing credit jury system urge senate pass important piece legislation would triumph civil rights equalitythis pride month must stay silent states consider pass transphobic homophobic policies threaten lgbtq community stand hate ensure love wins

content: Today, I had the chance to tour the progress being made at our new, expanded VA Clinic in New Port Richey. Construction of this state-of-the art facility is well underway, with an anticipated opening for fall of 2022. This modern, beautiful center will offer 25 new or expanded services which Pasco Veterans currently have to travel to Tampa to access. Veterans can learn more about these plans at an upcoming forum which will be held on July 7, 2021 at 5 p.m. at the Pasco County Board of County Commission Chamber in New Port Richey. name: James M. Inhofe
content:
Women are protected from discrimination under the law through the 14th Amendment to the Constitution, which says no state shall deny any person within its jurisdiction equal protection under the law. That’s pretty strong—and pretty clear as well. But just in case, women’s rights are also protected by the Equal Pay Act of 1963, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Pregnancy Discrimination Act of 1978 and more.

Read the op-ed I wrote with Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith in Fox News ⬇️

name: James R. Langevin
content:
If you come across a baby deer this month, don’t panic! They haven't been abandoned.

New mothers often leave their fawns somewhere safe while they gather food. Don't approach the fawn - Mom will be back.

Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management
Yesterday at 9:20 AM ·

DEM Urges Rhode Islanders Not to Remove Fawns and Other Baby Animals from the Wild

PROVIDENCE – The Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management (DEM) is cautioning the public not to assume that finding a baby animal means it needs to be rescued. For example, a fawn lying on the ground hidden in grass or brush should not be considered abandoned; it should be left alone.

White-tailed deer give birth to fawns in May and June. Each year, DEM receives many calls about fawns apparently being abandoned by their mother.

"This is almost never the case and most of these fawns are not abandoned," said Dylan Ferreira, a wildlife biologist in DEM's Division of Fish & Wildlife. "In nature, the mother deer gives birth and for the next five to seven days, the fawn is incapable of following the mother, so it is natural for the fawn to lie in a curled 'freeze' position on the ground hidden in grass or sparse brush. Sometimes, however, well-intentioned people will assume the fawn is abandoned and take it home to 'save' it from predators or domestic animals."

These fawns, however, have not been abandoned. "In fact, the doe will often be nearby, out of sight and will only come to the fawn a few times during the day or after dark to feed the fawn," Ferreira added. "If you see a fawn in this condition, please leave it alone, as the mother will return to feed it."

After seven to 10 days, the fawn may run when approached and after a month will be able to follow and feed alongside the mother. Interference by handling and taking fawns from the wild by people during this process can often doom young deer. If there is no dead doe found nearby or on the road, the fawn is not considered abandoned.

If you should find a fawn, the best thing to do is immediately leave the area and avoid creating any disturbance near it. Fawns should not be handled – and counter-intuitive as it may seem – do not need your help. Fawns are well camouflaged and have very little scent helping to protect it from predators, explains Ferreira.

Fawns also lie motionless when approached by a predator, a behavioral adaptation to help it survive. The doe-fawn bond is very strong and even in extreme cases if the fawn has been handled, it should be put back near the location where it was found or next to natural vegetation to provide some protection. Rarely, a fawn may approach people or pets. If this occurs, it should be gently coaxed back down into the grass by pressing down on its shoulders as its mother would. Then, DEM advises the public to immediately leave the area. Do not wait to see if the doe returns as she will avoid the area until the disturbance passes. She will return to search and care for the missing fawn once the area is clear of people and pets.

Fawns cannot be kept as pets and removing a deer from the wild and keeping it in captivity – however well-intentioned – is illegal in Rhode Island. Wild deer often do poorly in captivity, suffering malnutrition and behavioral changes as they become accustomed to humans. Captive deer also can pose health risks or may become dangerous to people or domestic animals as they mature. Tame deer raised in captivity have trouble returning to the wild as a free-roaming creature as nature intended. Any fawn obviously injured by a pet, vehicle, or farm equipment should be reported directly to the Division of Fish and Wildlife at 401-789-0281.

For more information on when it is appropriate to assist young wildlife, check out DEM's YouTube channel for a recording of the Division of Fish and Wildlife's recent outreach program here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jdRBiuJrj78&t=1s.

Follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/RhodeIslandDEM, Twitter @RhodeIslandDEM, and Instagram @RI.FishandWildlife for timely updates.

https://www.ri.gov/press/view/41266

name: Ken Calvert
content: Don Galleano was a leader in every sense of the word. He was also one of my closest friends and I am deeply saddened by his passing. Don proudly carried on his family’s legacy as a third-generation winegrower. Thanks to his dedication, the Galleano Winery carries on today as a landmark in the Jurupa Valley. Don’s service on the Board of Directors for the Western Municipal Water District and Metropolitan Water District highlight his countless contributions to addressing the water and agricultural needs of our region. Don brought an unrivaled passion and energy to everything he did in life, and he will be severely missed by many. My heartfelt condolences go out to the Galleano family as well as Don’s friends and colleagues.

name: Ted Lieu
content:
The Federal Writers' Project of the New Deal Era was an amazing project that helped unemployed writers get back on their feet. I was proud to work with David Kipen and Rep. Teresa Leger Fernández to introduce the 21st Century Federal Writers' Project to revive this crucial program for the post-COVID era. Our bill will not only help employ writers, editors, and photographers, but it will also help newsrooms in small towns and rural areas recover, and prevent important stories from going untold.

Watch our full interview with Los Angeles Times Today: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0LT-Iz03X6g

name: Peter A. DeFazio

name: Don Young
content:
I had a great meeting in Anchorage with the Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium's (ANTHC) leadership at the Alaska Native Medical Center campus. ANTHC works hard every single day to meet the unique health needs of Alaska Native communities. I was happy to have to chance to meet ANTHC's interim president, Valerie Nurr'araaluk Davidson. My late wife, daughters, and grandchildren are Alaska Native, so I am deeply grateful for her commitment to our state's First Peoples.

The COVID-19 pandemic hit our Alaska Native communities especially hard, but ANTHC rose to the occasion and created a response strategy that can serve as a model for health systems across the nation. Alaska continues making great progress, with over 53% of Alaskans having received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine. This is due in no small part to the incredible vaccination campaigns carried out by ANTHC and other Alaska Native health organizations. I want to thank Kirsten Kolb for overseeing vaccination efforts and, undoubtedly, helping to save countless lives.

Effective coordination between Alaska Native organizations and governments at all levels is critical. I want to thank Jerry Moses for his work as ANTHC's senior director of intergovernmental affairs. I look forward to our continued work together in the future.

I am now fully vaccinated against COVID-19, and am grateful to Valerie, Kirsten, and Jerry for also being fully vaccinated and leading by example. Thank you for hosting me and for a productive conversation!

name: Gregorio Kilili Camacho Sablan
content: Acting Assistant Secretary Dennis Alvord met with me on Wednesday to announce the Economic Development Administration is awarding $21.16 million for an Oleai Sports Complex and Cultural Events Center. Congress provided the funds for recovery from Super Typhoon Yutu in Public Law 116-20 in June 2019; and the Commonwealth submitted its sports/tourism complex application that December. Since the beginning of the year, EDA has increased the pace of grants for Yutu recovery, awarding $10.3 million to Northern Marianas Technical Institute, $13.2 million to Northern Marianas College, and $11.2 million for Garapan revitalization. Alvord told me proposals from the Marianas were highly competitive and, as a result, our islands are receiving a significant portion of the funding set aside in the 2019 appropriation. One application still outstanding is for the construction of a new building and software systems for the Commonwealth’s Department of Finance. Yutu destroyed the existing data storage facility, reducing the Department’s ability to produce accurate financial reports. An EDA grant would allow Finance to consolidate its scattered offices and data storage in one hardened location. Alvord acknowledged the application was taking time to review. Typically, he said, EDA construction grants are in the range of $2 to $3 million. The DOF project will cost over $22 million. This is the fourth EDA disaster recovery grant awarded this year.
text: acting assistant secretary dennis alvord met wednesday announce economic development administration awarding million oleai sports complex cultural events center congress provided funds recovery super typhoon yutu public law june commonwealth submitted sportstourism complex application december since beginning year eda increased pace grants yutu recovery awarding million northern marianas technical institute million northern marianas college million garapan revitalization alvord told proposals marianas highly competitive result islands receiving significant portion funding set aside appropriation one application still outstanding construction new building software systems commonwealths department finance yutu destroyed existing data storage facility reducing departments ability produce accurate financial reports eda grant would allow finance consolidate scattered offices data storage one hardened location alvord acknowledged application taking time review typically said eda construction grants range million dof project cost million fourth eda disaster recovery grant awarded year

name: Stacey E. Plaskett
content:
Washington, D.C. – Congresswoman Stacey E. Plaskett released the following statement regarding $1,066,500.00 in federal funding to the Virgin Islands Water and Power Authority (WAPA) for electrical distribution repairs on St. John:

“Today, I am pleased to announce a grant from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). The grant of $1,066,500.00 is federal funding to the Virgin Islands Water and Power Authority (WAPA) for electrical distribution repairs on St. John.

“Hurricane Maria made landfall bringing hurricane-force winds and heavy rains, causing catastrophic damages to the U.S. Virgin Islands, including St. John. As a result, WAPA suffered damages to the electrical distribution system and infrastructure on St. John. Approximately 90% of overhead power distribution was damaged, resulting in numerous outages to commercial and residential customers. In response, WAPA will use force account labor, equipment, and material and contractor services to restore the facilities to pre-disaster design, capacity, and function.

“This important grant will benefit the Virgin Islands, particularly St. John, tremendously in our ongoing rebuilding efforts. The United States government has an obligation to work with our territory to restore infrastructure, provide critical humanitarian assistance, and help rebuild our islands.”

###

Yesterday should have been Hadiya Pendleton's 24th birthday. Tragically, her life was cut short when she was shot in a Chicago park in 2013, just days after performing in festivities for President Obama's second inauguration. Last week I introduced the #WearOrange resolution to establish June 4th as Gun Violence Awareness Day and designate the month of June as Gun Violence Awareness Month.

I hope you will join me in honoring the life of Hadiya Pendleton and all other victims of gun violence tomorrow by wearing orange.

content:
Yesterday, I was honored to attend the groundbreaking for Mustacci Manor, designed for people with physical disabilities. It is the third such apartment complex built in Matteson since 2005. All three housing developments were made possible through the efforts of the Over the Rainbow Association, a human-centered organization dedicated to creating affordable, accessible housing for people with physical disabilities.

Upon the completion of Mustacci Manor, we will have additional housing in our community that will allow residents to live independently and affordably. I’m working in Washington to ensure we have MORE affordable, accessible housing in our communities.

name: Dan Sullivan
content:
More than eighty percent of Alaska’s communities are not on the road system, leaving many Alaskans largely dependent on air travel to reach the rest of the state and the outside world. But without the pilots, mechanics, engineers and professionals who operate and maintain our aircraft and transportation infrastructure, that connection will be lost. These jobs are so important to maintaining access to all corners of our state, and they also happen to be great opportunities for Alaskans to build a career and support a family at a time when many are out of work and struggling financially. I recently introduced legislation with Senators Peters and Cortez Masto to help fill the gaps in service and ensure we maintain a robust and capable workforce that can transport Alaskans and our goods.

SULLIVAN.SENATE.GOV
Sullivan, Peters, and Cortez Masto Reintroduce Bipartisan Legislation to Strengthen Transportation Industry Workforce | U.S. Senator Dan Sullivan of Alaska

content:
For the first time in 10 years, the Presidential budget proposal includes an increase in funding for East-West Center.

We worked hard in Congress to secure $19.7 million for East-West Center, and I’m pleased to see that President Biden recognizes the increasingly important role the Center plays in strengthening our national security and improving regional cooperation. Now, I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress and with the president to move this important funding forward.

As the cost of living rises and the shortage of affordable housing grows, community organizations are looking for creative ways to develop new affordable housing units near city centers or along accessible transit lines.

name: Markwayne Mullin
content:
Communities all across the Second Congressional District of Oklahoma are full of things that make them unique and I want to highlight some of them. Every week on my Facebook page, I will post an up-close photo of a landmark somewhere in the district with a clue to where it is. I encourage everyone to put their best guess in the comments. The correct answer will be in my weekly newsletter. You can subscribe to my newsletter here: https://mullin.house.gov/forms/form/?ID=1&fbclid=IwAR3xM-M1TULdUdh7Uv7b7lfjn1eg9fkpc0v93gCO57wTHZTf_gwImZ4oXfI

Hint: This Oklahoma landmark stands 1,999 ft above the surrounding terrain and derives its name from the French word meaning “cave.” Today, this landmark is the site of 5-mile runs, mountain bike races, and breathtaking panoramic views of the Poteau River Valley.

name: Frank Pallone, Jr.
content:
New Jersey will begin phasing out the COVID-19 vaccine mega-sites and instead transition to more community-based vaccination sites.

The Middlesex County mega-site in Edison will give its final round of first shots on June 26 and the last follow-up doses will be administered on July 17.

Governor Phil Murphy
June 2 at 1:18 PM ·

With close to 1,800 vaccination sites located across the state, we are now beginning to transition away from the mega-site model to the community-based model.

These sites have delivered nearly two million doses and fully vaccinated more than 950,000 people.

We outlined to the administrator how North Dakota is leading the way in preserving clean air and water, while also supporting economic growth, including our efforts to crack the code on CCUS and produce more energy with better environmental stewardship. We need a commonsense, state-led approach to regulations and we made that case to Administrator Regan today.

name: Derek Kilmer
content:
The #AmericanRescuePlan provided critical funding to get kids back to school safely, address lost learning time, and support student mental health. I enjoyed visiting Roosevelt Elementary in Port Angeles (the building where my dad worked!) to talk about how ARP investments are supporting the needs of students, teachers, and staff.

It was also terrific to hear from Port Angeles School District leaders about new safety and security improvements enabled by the 2020 Capital Levy. I even got to hear about the soon-to-come Monroe Fields, which will provide new sports fields for school and community use! Grateful for the work of all of the teachers, staff, administrators, and other leaders in the school district that made such a difference in my life!

North Dakota has long played an essential role in our nation’s defense and Collins Aerospace has been an important part of Jamestown for decades.

name: Stacey E. Plaskett
content:
Washington, DC – Congresswoman Stacey E. Plaskett, a member of the Ways and Means Committees, released the following statement on the announcement today of a global vaccine distribution:

“As a Co-Chair of the Congressional Caribbean and a member of the House Haiti Caucus, I applaud President Biden and his administration for answering our calls to introduce a competent global vaccination plan to support our neighbors — particularly Caribbean nations — who have been some of the hardest hit by the devastating effect of COVID-19. As long as this pandemic is raging anywhere in the world, we are all still vulnerable. I am proud the United States is committed to bringing the same urgency to international vaccination efforts that we have demonstrated right here at home. The allocation of approximately 6 million doses to the Caribbean and Latin America is a poignant step in the right direction that will dramatically stem the tide of COVID’s deadly progression in the region.

“Recently my office spearheaded a letter to Secretary of State Blinken highlighting the need for these vaccines in the Caribbean and other parts of the world.

“These vaccines are being shared to save lives and to lead the world in bringing an end to the pandemic and with the power of our example and with our values. And we will continue to follow the science and to work in close cooperation with our democratic partners to coordinate a multilateral effort. Strong American leadership is essential to ending this pandemic now, and to strengthening global health security for tomorrow—to better prevent, detect, and respond to the next threat.”
###
text: washington dc congresswoman stacey e plaskett member ways means committees released following statement announcement today global vaccine distributionas cochair congressional caribbean member house haiti caucus applaud president biden administration answering calls introduce competent global vaccination plan support neighbors particularly caribbean nations hardest hit devastating effect covid19 long pandemic raging anywhere world still vulnerable proud united states committed bringing urgency international vaccination efforts demonstrated right home allocation approximately million doses caribbean latin america poignant step right direction dramatically stem tide covids deadly progression regionrecently office spearheaded letter secretary state blinken highlighting need vaccines caribbean parts worldthese vaccines shared save lives lead world bringing end pandemic power example values continue follow science work close cooperation democratic partners coordinate multilateral effort strong american leadership essential ending pandemic strengthening global health security tomorrowto better prevent detect respond next threat

name: Brian Higgins

An estimated 110,000 veterans have Parkinson's Disease, some related to exposure to Agent Orange while serving. While exercise therapy has been proven to deliver promising results in slowing the progression of Parkinson's, the treatment is not a covered benefit under the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. In testimony before the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs we fought on behalf of veterans here in Western New York and others across the country fighting this difficult disease.
https://higgins.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/higgins-fights-for-veterans-with-parkinson-s-disease-to-have-access-to

name: Andy Barr
content:
Attention Flooding survivors: FEMA is hosting in-person appointments to help people in impacted counties register for individual assistance and answer any questions you may have due to the recent flooding and severe storms. Appointments are not required and you do NOT have to register in the county in which you live. Individual Assistance Registration Support Centers are available in Powell, Breathitt, and Johnson counties on June 5, 7 and 8, from 8 AM to 6 PM.

In Powell County, the Individual Assistance Registration Support Center will be held at the Clay City Church of God, 4200 Main Street, Clay City, Kentucky.

Find out more information here:

BARR.HOUSE.GOV
barr.house.gov

name: Garret Graves
content:
The State-run Louisiana Watershed Initiative recently announced a 2nd tranche of projects across Louisiana.

But $3 billion and three years later, South Louisiana should be flooded with protection projects. After the 2016 Flood we secured the $3 billion to tackle flood protection needs revealed by the 2016 flood and other risks.

Half was secured to clear the backlog of legacy flood projects and half to provide future protection against flood risks in South Louisiana. This is record funding to complete projects that had been stalled for decades and includes $1.2 billion in additional funding to deliver the best flood protection we’ve ever had.

Together, these projects will reduce flood risk for communities throughout the state.

Last week, Ascension, East Baton Rouge, Iberville and Lafourche parishes secured $22,709,500 - a result of these legislative efforts.

And money is an important part of the solution, but it doesn’t do any good sitting in the bank. We’re almost five years past the 2016 Flood, years after we secured the dollars and the money is slowly trickling out on localized projects.

I’m glad to see project announcements, but this process lacks the regional scale, urgency and transparency taxpayers deserve. A good bit of flooding from the May storm is preventable if we allocate the resources to the right projects with a greater sense of urgency. Some of the projects announced are crucial components to providing our communities, schools, homes and businesses the flood protection we need and deserve.
https://garretgraves.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/graves-statement-227-million-trickle-2018-federal-flood-funds

GARRETGRAVES.HOUSE.GOV
Graves Statement on $22.7 Million Trickle of 2018 Federal Flood Funds
text: staterun louisiana watershed initiative recently announced 2nd tranche projects across louisianabut billion three years later south louisiana flooded protection projects flood secured billion tackle flood protection needs revealed flood riskshalf secured clear backlog legacy flood projects half provide future protection flood risks south louisiana record funding complete projects stalled decades includes billion additional funding deliver best flood protection weve ever hadtogether projects reduce flood risk communities throughout statelast week ascension east baton rouge iberville lafourche parishes secured result legislative effortsand money important part solution doesnt good sitting bank almost five years past flood years secured dollars money slowly trickling localized projectsim glad see project announcements process lacks regional scale urgency transparency taxpayers deserve good bit flooding may storm preventable allocate resources right projects greater sense urgency projects announced crucial components providing communities schools homes businesses flood protection need deservegarretgraveshousegovgraves statement million trickle federal flood funds

name: Josh Gottheimer
content:
Alyssa Alhadeff, a North Jersey native, was killed in the tragic Parkland school shooting in 2018.

The Alyssa's Legacy Youth in School Safety Alert (ALYSSA) Act is dedicated to her, and the passage of this critical bill will help protect our kids in school nationwide.

Less than 1/3rd of schools report using silent alarms that are directly connected to local law enforcement. With this bipartisan legislation, we can help save lives.

name: House Committee on Education and Labor

name: House Budget Committee
content:
For too long, wealthy tax dodgers have exploited loopholes in our tax code, creating two tax systems:

1️⃣A tax system for hard-working Americans
2️⃣And another for the rich & powerful

But this is our moment to restore fairness and accountability. As five former IRS commissioners wrote in a recent Washington Post op-ed, President Joe Biden’s tax enforcement proposal will take a significant step toward creating a fairer tax system:

“The significant revenue at stake is a byproduct of the magnitude of the tax gap, which costs the country and honest taxpayers 3 percent of gross domestic product annually in taxes that are owed but unpaid. Uncollected taxes today equal the total taxes paid by the lower 90 percent of individual taxpayers. The scope of the tax compliance problem means that comprehensive proposals to address it would reap substantial benefits.”
text: long wealthy tax dodgers exploited loopholes tax code creating two tax systems1a tax system hardworking americans2and another rich powerfulbut moment restore fairness accountability five former irs commissioners wrote recent washington post oped president joe bidens tax enforcement proposal take significant step toward creating fairer tax systemthe significant revenue stake byproduct magnitude tax gap costs country honest taxpayers percent gross domestic product annually taxes owed unpaid uncollected taxes today equal total taxes paid lower percent individual taxpayers scope tax compliance problem means comprehensive proposals address would reap substantial benefits

name: U.S. Helsinki Commission
content:
The Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (also known as the Helsinki Commission)—was the brainchild of the courageous and tenacious Rep. Millicent Fenwick.

Rep. Fenwick’s activism was prompted by a 1975 visit to Russia, one week after the Helsinki Final Act was signed. As noted in Amy Shapiro’s book, “Millicent Fenwick: Her Way,” the visit brought on a revelation.

“You read about an automobile accident and you’re shocked,” Rep. Fenwick said. “But you come upon that accident and see the blood on the victims and hear their cries – how different it is. Well, that’s what it was like to go to Russia and hear the cries of all these desperate people.”

Witnessing such devastation first-hand, Rep. Fenwick leapt into action, becoming one of the two primary advocates for the creation of a U.S. body to observe and promote compliance with the human rights provisions of the Helsinki Final Act, alongside Sen. Clifford Case.

Rep. Fenwick became an original member of the Helsinki Commission and served as a commissioner until she retired from Congress.

Walter Cronkite called her “the conscience of Congress.” She remained a strong opponent of corruption and a driving advocate for human and civil rights throughout her lifetime.

#HelsinkiComm45

CSCE.GOV
Representative Millicent Fenwick

name: House Budget Committee
content:
For too long, wealthy tax dodgers have exploited loopholes in our tax code, creating two tax systems:

1️⃣A tax system for hard-working Americans
2️⃣And another for the rich & powerful

But this is our moment to restore fairness and accountability. As five former IRS commissioners wrote in a recent Washington Post op-ed, President Joe Biden’s tax enforcement proposal will take a significant step toward creating a fairer tax system:

“The significant revenue at stake is a byproduct of the magnitude of the tax gap, which costs the country and honest taxpayers 3 percent of gross domestic product annually in taxes that are owed but unpaid. Uncollected taxes today equal the total taxes paid by the lower 90 percent of individual taxpayers. The scope of the tax compliance problem means that comprehensive proposals to address it would reap substantial benefits.”

Read our full report on the importance of increasing IRS funding ➡️ https://budget.house.gov/publications/report/funding-irs

BUDGET.HOUSE.GOV
Funding the IRS Pays Off: Preventing Tax Dodging by Wealthy Filers Is the First Step to Fixing Our Tax Code
text: long wealthy tax dodgers exploited loopholes tax code creating two tax systems1a tax system hardworking americans2and another rich powerfulbut moment restore fairness accountability five former irs commissioners wrote recent washington post oped president joe bidens tax enforcement proposal take significant step toward creating fairer tax systemthe significant revenue stake byproduct magnitude tax gap costs country honest taxpayers percent gross domestic product annually taxes owed unpaid uncollected taxes today equal total taxes paid lower percent individual taxpayers scope tax compliance problem means comprehensive proposals address would reap substantial benefitsread full report importance increasing irs funding budgethousegovfunding irs pays preventing tax dodging wealthy filers first step fixing tax code

content:
It's important that we take the time to understand the experiences of members of the AAPI community, especially with the alarming rise in hate crimes due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

That's why I sat down with AAPI leaders from the 11th District-- Xilin Association Chairman Dr. Bill Liu, Representative Janet Yang Rohr and Sean Li, Naperville Central High School alumnus and an undergraduate research assistant at Duke University-- for a conversation about how we can support and protect our AAPI friends, neighbors, and loved ones.

Please take the time to watch this discussion.
